title: Nonorganic Hearing Loss in a Pediatric Patient
chief_complaint: I had a sudden change in my hearing in my right ear about 2 months ago. I have to ask my family to repeat themselves a lot, and I switched my phone to my left ear because it sounds clearer.

problem_summary.onset: Sudden onset approximately 2 months prior to the visit.
problem_summary.course: Stable since onset; patient reports continued difficulty.
problem_summary.laterality: Right ear reported; Left ear reported as better.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Intermittent pain in the left ear; history of migraine headaches. Denies tinnitus, dizziness, or aural fullness.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Requires frequent repetition with family; altered telephone use habits.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Diagnostic evaluation following a failed school hearing screening.

history.present_illness: Patient failed a school hearing screening. Reports sudden right-sided hearing loss 2 months ago. A previous test was done at another center last month (results unavailable).
history.otologic_history: No significant history of ear pathology. Intermittent left ear pain reported.
history.medical_psych_history: Significant history of migraine headaches. Normal developmental milestones.
history.prior_management: Hearing test at another center 1 month ago.
history.patient_goals: Determine hearing status after failed screening.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Normal hearing sensitivity bilaterally (0-10 dB HL). Initial responses in the right ear were inconsistent and elevated (mild to moderate levels), but thresholds normalized immediately after reinstruction and use of an ascending presentation method.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Speech Recognition Thresholds (SRT) were in agreement with pure-tone averages. Word Recognition Scores (WRS) were excellent bilaterally.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Reflexes present and normal for ipsilateral and contralateral stimulation at 500, 1000, 2000, and 4000 Hz. Reflex decay was negative.

overall_audiologic_summary: The evaluation reveals normal hearing sensitivity bilaterally with excellent speech recognition abilities. Middle ear function is normal. Although the patient initially presented with inconsistent responses suggestive of a mild-to-moderate right-sided loss, reinstruction resulted in reliable thresholds within normal limits, indicating a nonorganic component to the initial presentation.
counseling_points: Your hearing test results today indicate that you have normal hearing in both ears.
The tests show that your ears are healthy and the nerves are picking up very soft sounds perfectly.
We noticed some inconsistency at the beginning of the test, but once we clarified the instructions, your responses showed your hearing is actually quite good.
We recommend a follow-up test in 6 months to monitor your hearing, given your concerns.
We will refer you to an otologist to double-check the intermittent pain you mentioned in your left ear.
notes_for_actor: Portray a teenager who is cooperative but initially vague or hesitant during the hearing test.
During the initial beep test for the right ear, do not press the button for soft sounds; wait until the sounds are moderately loud before responding.
If the audiologist stops and firmly but kindly explains that you need to push the button even for the tiniest beep, change your behavior and start responding normally to soft sounds.
Maintain that you feel like you can't hear well on the right side, even if the doctor tells you the test is normal.
